question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2020-08-04 23:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/4919). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

According to GiveWell's [Cost-Effectiveness Analysis](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zLmPuddUmKsy3v55AfG_e1Quk-ngDdNzW-FDx0T-Y94) (CEA), mass deworming ranks among the very best global health interventions. The evidence for deworming comes primarily from a [single study](https://www.nber.org/papers/w21428), which showed large economic effects which were present a full decade after treatment. However, other studies have shown [little](https://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30242-X/fulltext) to [no effect](https://www.cochrane.org/CD000371/INFECTN_deworming-school-children-low-and-middle-income-countries) of mass deworming on weight, cognitive ability, school attendance or other health outcomes, and the weight placed on the initial paper has proved [controversial](https://www.vox.com/2015/7/24/9031909/worm-wars-explained).

In GiveWell's CEA, deworming benefits are modeled as being entirely due to long-term economic effects like those seen in the study mentioned above. Despite being heavily discounted due to concerns about replicability, in expectation these economic effects are expected to dominate the short term health effects of the interventions.

Givewell's position is explained, in detail, in the following two blog posts:

- [Why I mostly believe in Worms](https://blog.givewell.org/2016/12/06/why-i-mostly-believe-in-worms/)

- [How thin the reed](https://blog.givewell.org/2017/01/04/how-thin-the-reed-generalizing-from-worms-at-work/)

Some more information is available in [this](https://www.givewell.org/international/technical/programs/deworming) evidence overview, written by GiveWell, which cites several papers, and [this](https://www.evidenceaction.org/a-summary-of-the-deworming-evidence-base/) evidence overview, which was written by Evidence Action. While Evidence Action does currently run a deworming programme, they have proved [capable](https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/2019/6/7/18654620/evidence-action-no-lean-season-givewell) of changing their minds on programmes when the evidence changes.

Currently, GiveWell lists seven [top charities](), of which four are deworming programmes.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
**At the end of 2025, will any of GiveWell's top charities perform mass deworming as their primary intervention?**

- Resolution will be according to the GiveWell [website](https://www.givewell.org/) on 2026/01/01.

- If GiveWell no longer maintains a list of "top charities", but allows donors to donate funds which will be re-granted at GiveWell's discretion, this question resolves positively if at least 10% of these regrants go to deworming charities in the year 2025.

- "Mass deworming" is taken to mean treating all or almost all of the individuals in a group for parasitic worms, without testing to see whether they have them. This is common practice due to the low cost and excellent safety profile of deworming medication, as well as the relative expense of testing.

- If a charity has multiple programmes, but GiveWell restricts its donations to a particular programme, that programme is considered to be the "primary intervention" for the purposes of resolution. Otherwise, whichever intervention the organisation spends most on is considered the "primary intervention".

- If deworming medication is administered in addition to something else, for example a vaccine or vitamin supplement, at the same time, then whether "deworming" is the primary intervention will be determined by whether the majority of the value of the programme comes from deworming, according to GiveWell's CEA.

- If GiveWell ceases to exist in a similar form, such that neither of the conditions for positive resolution above make sense, this question resolves ambiguously.

- Some of the text in this question has been adapted from [this](https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/FAA22RbfgC68fRnRs/if-you-mostly-believe-in-worms-what-should-you-think-about) EA forum post, by the same author.

**Active remote monitoring of long-term conditions with mobile devices: a systematic review of cost-effectiveness analyses - npj Digital Medicine**
A systematic review of cost-effectiveness analyses (CEAs) published in npj Digital Medicine examined seven studies on mobile device-based active remote monitoring for long-term health conditions. Six of the seven studies found the interventions to be cost-effective, with four showing they were 'dominant'—improving health outcomes (measured in quality-adjusted life years) while reducing healthcare costs. However, significant uncertainty exists in the joint distribution of incremental costs and health outcomes, which may hinder widespread adoption by decision-makers. The review highlights methodological limitations, including underreporting of health economic analysis plans, distributional effects, and patient engagement impacts due to recent reporting standards. No study conducted subgroup analyses to assess how population heterogeneity influenced cost-effectiveness. Most studies used trial-based designs, with uncertainty possibly due to non-inferiority/feasibility trial designs, underpowered superiority trials, or disparities in digital literacy and adherence. Decision-analytic models were underused (only two studies), despite their ability to extrapolate outcomes over lifetime horizons and support early-stage product development. Costing methods varied widely—top-down costing yielded substantially lower estimates than bottom-up micro-costing—suggesting potential underestimation of system costs if key resources are omitted. The review also notes that external dashboards, while easier to set up, impose workflow burdens on healthcare staff, and full integration with electronic health records requires significant infrastructure investment. Future research should prioritize decision-analytic modeling, explore non-randomized quasi-experimental designs, and investigate optimal monitoring frequencies. Additionally, broader perspectives beyond healthcare systems—such as patient time costs and travel savings—should be incorporated. The findings support the potential of mobile-based remote monitoring but caution that current evidence is insufficient to justify broad adoption due to persistent uncertainty. Developers and analysts are urged to improve transparency in upfront cost reporting and deepen exploration of uncertainty drivers to strengthen value propositions.

The study highlights that Mexico, which declared an epidemiological emergency for obesity and diabetes in 2016, has delayed implementing SSB tax increases since at least 2018, with no change as of February 2025. The findings emphasize the importance of quantifying the 'cost-of-delay' in public health, particularly for population-level interventions. However, over time, earlier interventions produce far greater cumulative benefits. The study also notes limitations, including reliance on meta-analytic mortality hazard ratios, assumptions about energy intake trends, conservative price elasticity estimates, and a closed cohort model that excludes future generations. Despite these, the results consistently support the urgency of timely implementation of evidence-based fiscal policies to combat obesity and related chronic diseases. The authors advocate for incorporating temporal dimensions into future public health modeling to better assess the real-world impact of policy delays.

Some patients use acupuncture for severe conditions like dementia, stroke, or infertility, but evidence does not support efficacy. A systematic analysis of 33 studies concluded acupuncture did not improve neurological outcomes, with positive results attributed to bias and placebo effects. summary: Across all expert perspectives, there is an overwhelming consensus that at the end of 2025, at least one of GiveWell's top charities will perform mass deworming as its primary intervention. All forecasters point to the historical persistence and status quo inertia of deworming on GiveWell’s top charity list, the lack of any major new negative evidence or sectoral scandal in 2025, and GiveWell's cautious, deliberative process for updating recommendations. Several note that GiveWell’s cost-effectiveness models, even when deeply discounting for evidentiary uncertainty, continue to rank mass deworming among the most cost-effective interventions. The possibility for abrupt removal is considered only if a major, credible new randomized trial or meta-analysis emerges before year-end or if GiveWell’s operational model shifts so substantially that discretionary grantmaking drops deworming below 10% of funds—neither of which is currently suggested by news or sector developments. Other factors supporting a high probability of continued deworming recommendations include operational stability of deworming charities, sustained demand from national governments, the absence of major donor revolt, and the fine print of the resolution criteria allowing for a positive outcome under various scenarios. Across all responses, probability estimates for a Yes outcome cluster tightly in the mid- to high-90s percentile range (94-98%), with only minor discounts for theoretical tail risks such as unforeseen evidence shocks or scandals.
